instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL is a clock line on the data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA is a data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_3_SDA is the SMBUS data line between the trackpad temperature sensor, temperature sensors, and the system management controller(SMC). .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
My customer brought me a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B and had a coke liquid on it. We have changed the infected parts of the mainboard. But still no power.

And I have checked all big coils on diode mode. Found short on PP3V42 but thats been sorted. But still have voltages written below after short gone. I saw green and orange light once then <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> burned out. Changed it with another one from donor board. It was okay saw the green and orange light again for a second and again no more. Any ideas where to check?

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0.V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.7V on <RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR>
Pp3v42 = 1.6V on L7095
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V on <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.6V on <CAPACITOR>C8180</CAPACITOR>
L7130 = Starts with 0.6V and goes down
L7520 = 0V
L7560 = 0V
L7430 = 0V
L7630 = 0V

Thank You

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
With such low voltages, did you check diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Also check at <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.175 on diode mode
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.379 on diode mode
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 0.003V
Pin 2 = 16.70V
Pin 3 = 4.44V
Pin 9 = 0.065V
Pin 12 = 1.62V
Pin 13 = 0.001V
Pin 14 = 1.56V
Pin 15 = 0.60V
Pin 17 = 0.006V on 
Pin 19 = 5.06V on 
Pin 20 = 5.06V on 
Pin 27 = 16.49V on 

<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> On diode mode
Pin 1 = OL
Pin 4 = 2850 on C 7012
Pin 6 = 2967 on <CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR>

<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> Voltages:

Pin 1 = 16.92V
Pin 4 = 6.85V
Pin 6 = 16.90V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
Check R/<DIODE>D7005</DIODE>.
Post <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.

Also check resistance (ohm scale) between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> ON DIODE OL ON BOTH LEGS
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> ON DIODE MODE
PIN 1 = 0.177
PIN 2 = OL
PIN 3 = 0.405

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> VOLTAGES
PIN1 = 16.95V
PIN 2 = 2.65V
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> VOLTAGES
PIN 1 = 0.520v
PIN 2 = 2.66v
PIN 3= 2.40V

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> VOLTAGES
PIN1 = 0.84V
PIN2 = 1.61V
PIN3 = 1.60V and keeps going down while holding
PIN4 =1.60v
PIN5 = GND
PIN6 = 2.40V
PIN7 = 3.40V keeps going down while holding
PIN8 = 2.40V

Resistance Scale Between 17/18 Pins = 3.5 If I did it right. First time Im doing this :)
Resistance Scale Between 27/28 Pins = 20.5

threads.message: I have inspected 2 more problem one of them  is booting the macos. It takes ages to boot the macos and it shuts itself on login screen after a while. And also it does not recognize battery and charging of course and no keyboard or trackpad working

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
This Mac is plenty of problems.

Did PRAM reset?
KB/TP also not working on boot menu ?
Tried known good trackpad flex/board?

Check diode mode to ground and voltage on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
KB /TP are working well did PRAM reset but still booting in ages.

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.583 on DIODE Mode
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.552 on DIODE Mode
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 2.724 on DIODe Mode

When I put the battery on and plug in the charging cable I get 2.2V on <CAPACITOR>C6950</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6951</CAPACITOR> I think the problem is the battery but not for sure.

And what do you think about macbook starst so slow and on login screen after like 20 seconds it shuts itself done. Where can it be happening?
I did PRAM reset and SMC reset

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.583 on DIODE Mode
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0.552 on DIODE Mode
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 2.724 on DIODe Mode"
Has this any sense for you?
I asked about SCL and SDA; any reason to post 3 times SCL, with such different readings???

Test with another battery, or check its battery with battery tester.
NLBA is the best tool for this purpose:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.laptopu.ro/[/URL]

About slow machine, try known good BIOS, clean ME.

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
So many SCL/SDA lines go to your battery???
We talk about battery bus here.
I didn't see its SCL there; unless you've named it "S0" by error.
Try to post what we need, without irrelevant checkings; which can only complicate the job.

0.553/0.550 is good enough for diode mode.
Still no idea about their voltage.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.cmizapper.com/products/medusa-3.html[/URL]
Many other useful tools there...

threads.message:
Hello again, my CH341 bios programmer just arrived (as this is the only one I could find.) First I tried it with its latch but unfortunately it is not touching the pins of the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> so I tried to took the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> off from the board and tried to reprogramme it on the device. But it didnt work again. I have read that some computers need power on but I dont if I need to do it. 
But in anyway I dont know if I am doing everything right or am I missing anything else?
Thank you for being patient with me. 

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
Are you getting good contacts for the WSON chip on the CH341 socket?
You can also use classic SOP-8 chip, like MX25L6405 for this board, at least for test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Power No Green Light No Orange Light
threads.message:
I had succeded on reading chip but I realised that you can see on video. The chip must be programmed as 3.3v but when I choose the chip after detect it comes as 1.8V. And you can see what I am doing step by step on video. Am I doing anything wrong or missing? Because after I programme the chip I click on verify but it gives me an error that you can see on attached photo and after I put this chip on board it does not boot (no apple logo or anything. It was booting before but it was slow.) Do I need to do any modification or something to force ch341 to programme the chip as 3.3V?
